title: Agency
description: Agency flashcards for bar exam prep

cards.subject: Agency
cards.backPlain: Agency is a legal relationship between a principal and an agent, in which the agent acts on the principal’s behalf and is subject to the principal’s control. Agency law focuses on: 1. The core definition of an agency relationship. 2. When an agency relationship is created (consent, control, and acting on behalf of the principal). 3. The main methods by which agency can arise (agreement, apparent authority, and ratification).
cards.frontPrompt: What is an agency relationship, and at a high level, what are the main requirements and methods for its creation?
cards.cloze: Agency is a legal relationship between a {{c1::principal}} and an {{c2::agent}}, in which the agent acts on the principal’s behalf and is subject to the principal’s control. Agency creation turns on {{c3::consent}}, {{c4::control}}, and {{c5::acting on behalf}}, and agency can arise by {{c6::agreement}}, {{c7::apparent authority}}, or {{c8::ratification}}.
cards.easyContent: Agency is a relationship where an agent acts on a principal’s behalf and is subject to the principal’s control. Creation turns on consent, control, and acting on behalf, and agency can arise by agreement, apparent authority, or ratification.
cards.mediumContent: Agency is a relationship between a principal and an agent, where the agent acts on the principal’s behalf and is subject to the principal’s control. Creation requires consent, control, and acting on behalf of the principal. Agency can arise by agreement of the parties, by apparent authority (when the principal holds someone out as an agent), or by ratification (when the principal later agrees to be bound by an unauthorized act).
cards.hardContent: Agency is a legal relationship between a principal and an agent in which the agent acts on the principal’s behalf and is subject to the principal’s control. An agency relationship is created when (1) the parties consent to an agency relationship, (2) the principal has the right to control the agent, and (3) the agent is acting on behalf of the principal. Agency can arise by agreement of the parties, by apparent authority (the principal holds another out as an agent to a third party), or by ratification (the principal retroactively agrees to be bound by a previously unauthorized act). This card provides a high-level overview; see the child cards for details on creation elements and methods.
cards.mnemonic: Agency creation requires CCA: Consent, Control, Acting on behalf.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) definition of agency, (2) elements of creation (consent, control, acting on behalf), (3) methods of creation (agreement, apparent authority, ratification).
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::agency relationship}} exists when an {{c2::agent acts on a principal’s behalf}} and is {{c3::subject to the principal’s control}}; creation requires {{c4::consent, control, and acting on behalf}} and may arise by {{c5::agreement, apparent authority, or ratification}}.

cards.subject: Agency
cards.backPlain: An agency relationship can end by act or agreement of the parties or by operation of law. 1. Termination by parties (agency can be terminated by the parties where): 1.1 Party desire: either party manifests to the other the desire to terminate the agency relationship (termination is effective when notice is received); 1.2 Expiration: the express terms of the agency expire; and 1.3 Purpose fulfilled: the purpose of the agency relationship has been fulfilled. 2. Termination by operation of law (can occur where): 2.1 The agent or principal dies; 2.2 The agent or principal loses capacity; and/or 2.3 The agent materially breaches a fiduciary duty owed to the principal.
cards.frontPrompt: How can an agency relationship be terminated by the parties and by operation of law?
cards.cloze: An agency relationship can end by {{c1::act or agreement of the parties}} or by {{c2::operation of law}}. 1. Termination by parties (agency can be terminated by the parties where): 1.1 {{c3::Party desire}}: either party manifests to the other the desire to terminate the agency relationship (termination is effective when {{c4::notice is received}}); 1.2 {{c5::Expiration}}: the express terms of the agency expire; and 1.3 {{c6::Purpose fulfilled}}: the purpose of the agency relationship has been fulfilled. 2. Termination by operation of law (can occur where): 2.1 The agent or principal {{c7::dies}}; 2.2 The agent or principal {{c8::loses capacity}}; and/or 2.3 The agent {{c9::materially breaches a fiduciary duty}} owed to the principal.
cards.easyContent: Agency ends either by acts or agreement of the parties or automatically by operation of law, such as death, loss of capacity, or serious breach of duty.
cards.mediumContent: Agency can be terminated by the parties when either party manifests a desire to end the relationship (effective when notice is received), when the express term of the agency expires, or when the agency purpose is fulfilled. It can also terminate by operation of law upon the death or loss of capacity of either the agent or principal, or when the agent materially breaches a fiduciary duty owed to the principal.
cards.hardContent: An agency relationship can end by act or agreement of the parties or by operation of law. Termination by the parties includes: (1) party desire— either party manifests to the other the desire to terminate the relationship, effective when notice is received; (2) expiration— the express term of the agency expires; and (3) purpose fulfilled— the objective of the agency has been achieved. Termination by operation of law occurs where: (1) the agent or principal dies; (2) the agent or principal loses capacity; and/or (3) the agent materially breaches a fiduciary duty owed to the principal.
cards.mnemonic: DIE: Death, Incapacity, fiduciary Error (material breach).
cards.clozeLite: Agency ends by {{c1::act or agreement of the parties}} or by {{c2::operation of law}} like {{c3::death}}, {{c4::incapacity}}, or {{c5::material fiduciary breach}}.

cards.subject: Agency
cards.rawHeader: Agency 003. Duties of Agent to Principal
cards.backPlain: In the absence of anything contrary in their agreement, the agent owes the principal duties of loyalty, obedience, and care. 1. Loyalty: 1.1 The agent has a fiduciary duty of undivided loyalty to the principal; 1.2 The agent breaches this duty if he has adverse interests and fails to disclose such interests; and 1.3 The agent cannot act on behalf of two different principals with adverse interests. 2. Obedience: 2.1 The agent must obey the principal's lawful instructions; and 2.2 The agent's interpretation of the principal's instructions must be reasonable under the circumstances. 3. Care: 3.1 The agent must carry out his agency with reasonable care; 3.2 Reasonable care is judged in light of local community standards; and 3.3 A duty to notify is included in the duty of care: the agent must notify the principal of all agency-related matters that come to the agent's attention, and all such matters are imputed to the principal.
cards.frontPrompt: What default duties does an agent owe to a principal, and what does each duty require?
cards.cloze: In the absence of anything contrary in their agreement, the agent owes the principal duties of {{c1::loyalty}}, {{c2::obedience}}, and {{c3::care}}. 1. {{c4::Loyalty}}: 1.1 The agent has a {{c5::fiduciary duty of undivided loyalty}} to the principal; 1.2 The agent breaches this duty if he has {{c6::adverse interests}} and fails to disclose such interests; and 1.3 The agent cannot act on behalf of two different principals with {{c7::adverse interests}}. 2. {{c8::Obedience}}: 2.1 The agent must obey the principal's {{c9::lawful instructions}}; and 2.2 The agent's interpretation of the principal's instructions must be {{c10::reasonable under the circumstances}}. 3. {{c11::Care}}: 3.1 The agent must carry out his agency with {{c12::reasonable care}}; 3.2 Reasonable care is judged in light of {{c13::local community standards}}; and 3.3 A {{c14::duty to notify}} is included in the duty of care: the agent must notify the principal of all agency-related matters that come to the agent's attention, and all such matters are {{c15::imputed to the principal}}.
cards.easyContent: By default, an agent owes the principal duties of loyalty, obedience, and reasonable care, including a duty to notify the principal of relevant matters.
cards.mediumContent: Unless the agreement provides otherwise, an agent owes the principal: (1) a duty of loyalty— a fiduciary duty of undivided loyalty, with no undisclosed adverse interests or acting for principals with adverse interests; (2) a duty of obedience— to follow the principal’s lawful instructions reasonably; and (3) a duty of care— to act with reasonable care judged by local standards and to notify the principal of all agency-related matters, which are imputed to the principal.
cards.hardContent: Absent a contrary agreement, an agent owes the principal three core duties: loyalty, obedience, and care. The duty of loyalty requires the agent to act with a fiduciary duty of undivided loyalty, not to have undisclosed adverse interests, and not to act simultaneously for different principals with adverse interests. The duty of obedience requires the agent to obey the principal’s lawful instructions and to interpret those instructions reasonably under the circumstances. The duty of care requires the agent to perform with reasonable care as judged by local community standards, and includes a duty to notify the principal of all agency-related matters that come to the agent's attention; those matters are imputed to the principal.
cards.mnemonic: Agent’s core duties to the principal are LOC: Loyalty, Obedience, Care.
cards.clozeLite: An agent owes three default duties to the principal: {{c1::loyalty}}, {{c2::obedience}}, and {{c3::reasonable care}} (including {{c4::duty to notify}}).

cards.subject: Agency
cards.rawHeader: Agency 004. Duties of Principal to Agent
cards.backPlain: In the absence of anything to the contrary in their agreement, the principal owes the agent duties of compensation, reimbursement (including indemnification), and cooperation. 1. Compensation: unless the agent agrees to act gratuitously, the principal owes the agent a duty to compensate him reasonably. 2. Reimbursement and indemnification: the principal must reimburse and indemnify the agent for all expenses and losses reasonably incurred in carrying out the agent's duties, including legal liability incurred by the agent. 3. Cooperation: the principal must cooperate with the agent to help the agent carry out agency functions.
cards.frontPrompt: What default duties does a principal owe to an agent?
cards.cloze: In the absence of anything to the contrary in their agreement, the principal owes the agent duties of {{c1::compensation}}, {{c2::reimbursement and indemnification}}, and {{c3::cooperation}}. 1. {{c4::Compensation}}: unless the agent agrees to act gratuitously, the principal owes the agent a duty to compensate him reasonably. 2. {{c5::Reimbursement and indemnification}}: the principal must reimburse and indemnify the agent for all {{c6::expenses and losses reasonably incurred}} in carrying out the agent's duties, including {{c7::legal liability}} incurred by the agent. 3. {{c8::Cooperation}}: the principal must cooperate with the agent to help the agent carry out agency functions.
cards.easyContent: By default, a principal must reasonably compensate the agent, reimburse and indemnify the agent for reasonable expenses and losses, and cooperate with the agent’s performance of duties.
cards.mediumContent: Unless otherwise agreed, the principal owes the agent: (1) reasonable compensation, unless the agent agreed to act gratuitously; (2) reimbursement and indemnification for expenses, losses, and legal liability reasonably incurred in carrying out agency duties; and (3) cooperation by assisting the agent in performing agency functions.
cards.hardContent: Absent a contrary agreement, the principal owes the agent three main duties: (1) compensation— to pay the agent reasonable compensation unless the agent agreed to act gratuitously; (2) reimbursement and indemnification— to reimburse and indemnify the agent for all expenses and losses reasonably incurred in carrying out the agent’s duties, including legal liability incurred by the agent; and (3) cooperation— to cooperate with the agent so that the agent can effectively carry out agency functions.
cards.mnemonic: Principal’s duties to the agent are CRC: Compensation, Reimbursement, Cooperation.
cards.clozeLite: By default, a principal owes an agent {{c1::reasonable compensation}}, {{c2::reimbursement and indemnification}}, and {{c3::cooperation}}.

cards.subject: Agency
cards.rawHeader: Agency 005. Agent Authority & Principal Liability Basics
cards.backPlain: A person is generally not liable for the acts of another unless that other person has been made the person's representative and given the power to bind them. In agency law, a principal can be bound to a contract made by another only when that person is acting as the principal’s agent with power to bind the principal. This power to bind can arise through three main bases: 1. Actual authority. 2. Apparent authority. 3. Ratification. To analyze whether a principal is bound by an agent’s contract with a third party, apply a structured sequence: 1. Ask whether the agent had actual authority. 2. If not, ask whether there was apparent authority. 3. If neither exists, ask whether the principal nonetheless became bound through ratification. Each basis of authority has distinct consequences for whether the principal is bound and whether the agent may be liable to the principal.
cards.frontPrompt: In agency law, when can a principal be bound by another’s acts, and what are the three main bases of authority to analyze?
cards.cloze: A person is generally not liable for the acts of another unless that other person has been made the person's {{c1::representative}} and given the {{c2::power to bind}} them. In agency law, a principal can be bound to a contract made by another only when that person is acting as the principal’s {{c3::agent}} with power to bind the principal. This power to bind can arise through three main bases: 1. {{c4::Actual authority}}. 2. {{c5::Apparent authority}}. 3. {{c6::Ratification}}. To analyze whether a principal is bound by an agent’s contract with a third party, apply a structured sequence: 1. Ask whether the agent had {{c7::actual authority}}. 2. If not, ask whether there was {{c8::apparent authority}}. 3. If neither exists, ask whether the principal nonetheless became bound through {{c9::ratification}}.
cards.easyContent: A principal is generally only bound by another’s acts when that person is an agent with power to bind the principal. That power can come from actual authority, apparent authority, or ratification, which should be analyzed in that order.
cards.mediumContent: A person is not usually liable for another’s acts unless that person is made their representative with power to bind them. In agency, a principal can be bound to a contract made by an agent if: (1) the agent had actual authority, (2) even without actual authority, the agent had apparent authority, or (3) the principal later ratifies the unauthorized act. These three bases form the roadmap for analyzing principal liability for an agent’s contracts.
cards.hardContent: A principal is generally not liable for the acts of another unless that person has been made the principal’s representative and given the power to bind the principal. In agency, this binding power arises through three main bases of authority: (1) actual authority, (2) apparent authority, and (3) ratification. When determining whether a principal is bound by an alleged agent’s contract with a third party, follow a structured approach: first ask whether the agent had actual authority; if not, examine whether the agent had apparent authority; and if neither actual nor apparent authority is present, ask whether the principal nevertheless became bound by ratifying the agent’s unauthorized conduct. Each basis has its own consequences for principal liability and potential agent liability to the principal.
cards.mnemonic: When is P bound? AAR: Actual, Apparent, Ratification.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) overview & three bases of authority (parent); (2) stepwise analysis focusing on actual authority; (3) apparent authority and ratification and their consequences.
cards.clozeLite: A principal is bound when an agent has {{c1::actual authority}}, {{c2::apparent authority}}, or the principal {{c3::ratifies}} the act.

cards.subject: Agency
cards.backPlain: An agent acts with actual authority when, at the time of taking an act having legal consequences for the principal, the agent reasonably believes that the principal wishes the agent to act. Actual authority is the authority the agent reasonably believes he possesses based on his dealings with the principal. 1. Express vs. implied actual authority 1.1 Express actual authority: authority expressly provided to the agent by the principal (in writing or orally from principal to agent). For example, if the principal directs the agent to engage in a precise task, in doing so, the agent has express actual authority. 1.2 Implied actual authority: authority the agent reasonably believes he has based on the principal's actions (words or conduct). This includes incidental acts taken by the agent that are reasonably necessary to complete a task or transaction on the principal's behalf. For example, if the principal tells the agent to hire an employee, the agent has authority to take actions reasonably necessary to do so (such as placing a job posting and interviewing candidates). 2. Termination 2.1 Lapse of time (specified or unspecified). 2.2 Happening of an agreed-upon event. 2.3 Change of circumstances, or other similar events that make it unreasonable for the agent to believe he still has authority.
cards.frontPrompt: What is actual authority in agency law, how do express and implied actual authority differ, and how can actual authority terminate?
cards.cloze: An agent acts with {{c1::actual authority}} when, at the time of taking an act having legal consequences for the principal, the agent {{c2::reasonably believes that the principal wishes the agent to act}}. Actual authority is the authority the agent reasonably believes he possesses based on his dealings with the principal. 1. {{c3::Express vs. implied actual authority}} 1.1 {{c4::Express actual authority}}: authority expressly provided to the agent by the principal (in writing or orally from principal to agent). For example, if the principal directs the agent to engage in a precise task, in doing so, the agent has express actual authority. 1.2 {{c5::Implied actual authority}}: authority the agent reasonably believes he has based on the principal's actions (words or conduct). This includes {{c6::incidental acts reasonably necessary}} to complete a task or transaction on the principal's behalf. For example, if the principal tells the agent to hire an employee, the agent has authority to take actions reasonably necessary to do so (such as placing a job posting and interviewing candidates). 2. {{c7::Termination}} 2.1 {{c8::Lapse of time}} (specified or unspecified). 2.2 {{c9::Happening of an agreed-upon event}}. 2.3 {{c10::Change of circumstances}} or other similar events that make it unreasonable for the agent to believe he still has authority.
cards.easyContent: Actual authority exists when the agent reasonably believes, based on the principal’s manifestations, that the principal wants the agent to act. It may be given expressly or implied from the principal’s words or conduct.
cards.mediumContent: Actual authority is the authority an agent reasonably believes he has, based on the principal’s words or conduct, at the time he acts. It can be express (specifically given in words, written or oral) or implied (authority reasonably believed to exist, including incidental acts necessary to carry out an assigned task). Actual authority terminates by lapse of time, occurrence of an agreed event, or changed circumstances making the belief in authority unreasonable.
cards.hardContent: An agent acts with actual authority when, at the time of taking an act with legal consequences for the principal, the agent reasonably believes the principal wishes him to act. Actual authority is the authority the agent reasonably believes he possesses based on dealings with the principal. It includes: 1. Express actual authority: authority expressly provided by the principal, in writing or orally, such as directing the agent to perform a specific task. 2. Implied actual authority: authority the agent reasonably believes he has from the principal’s words or conduct, including incidental acts reasonably necessary to complete the assigned task or transaction. Actual authority terminates through: (a) lapse of time (specified or unspecified), (b) occurrence of an agreed-upon event, or (c) changes in circumstances or similar events that make it unreasonable for the agent to believe the authority continues.
cards.mnemonic: Actual = Agent Actually believes, based on principal.
cards.clozeLite: Actual authority exists when an agent {{c1::reasonably believes he has power}} based on {{c2::the principal’s words or conduct}}; it includes {{c3::express}} and {{c4::implied}} authority and {{c5::terminates when that belief becomes unreasonable}}.

cards.subject: Agency
cards.backPlain: Even when an agent lacks actual authority, the principal can be held liable for the agent's acts if the agent acted with apparent authority. The agent's acts will be binding on the principal if a third party can show that the agent acted with apparent authority. If a third party knows that the agent does not have actual authority, apparent authority does not exist. 1. Requirements (agent acts with apparent authority if): 1.1 The principal holds the agent out as having authority to act on the principal's behalf; and 1.2 The principal's conduct causes a third party to reasonably rely on the agent's appearance of authority. 2. Principal's manifestation required 2.1 The principal must affirmatively act or fail to act in a way that causes the third party's reasonable belief; a mere assertion of authority by the agent is insufficient to bind the principal. 2.2 Affirmative act: words or conduct by the principal that cause the third party's reasonable belief in the agent's authority. 2.3 Inaction: inaction by the principal, where a duty to act exists, that causes the third party's reasonable belief in the agent's authority (for example, where the principal knows the third party wrongly believes the agent has authority to act, the principal has a duty to correct). 3. Comparison to actual authority 3.1 Apparent authority: based on the principal's words or conduct, the reasonable third party believes that the agent is authorized. 3.2 Actual authority: based on the principal's words or conduct, the reasonable agent believes that he is authorized.
cards.frontPrompt: When does an agent have apparent authority, what manifestations by the principal are required, and how does apparent authority differ from actual authority?
cards.cloze: Even when an agent lacks {{c1::actual authority}}, the principal can be held liable for the agent's acts if the agent acted with {{c2::apparent authority}}. The agent's acts will be binding on the principal if a {{c3::third party}} can show that the agent acted with apparent authority. If a third party {{c4::knows the agent lacks actual authority}}, apparent authority does not exist. 1. {{c5::Requirements}} (agent acts with apparent authority if): 1.1 The principal {{c6::holds the agent out as having authority}} to act on the principal's behalf; and 1.2 The principal's conduct causes a third party to {{c7::reasonably rely}} on the agent's appearance of authority. 2. {{c8::Principal's manifestation required}} 2.1 The principal must {{c9::affirmatively act or fail to act}} in a way that causes the third party's reasonable belief; a mere {{c10::assertion of authority by the agent}} is insufficient to bind the principal. 2.2 {{c11::Affirmative act}}: words or conduct by the principal that cause the third party's reasonable belief in the agent's authority. 2.3 {{c12::Inaction}}: inaction by the principal, where a duty to act exists, that causes the third party's reasonable belief in the agent's authority (for example, where the principal knows the third party wrongly believes the agent has authority to act, the principal has a duty to correct). 3. {{c13::Comparison to actual authority}} 3.1 Apparent authority: based on the principal's words or conduct, the {{c14::reasonable third party}} believes that the agent is authorized. 3.2 Actual authority: based on the principal's words or conduct, the {{c15::reasonable agent}} believes that he is authorized.
cards.easyContent: Apparent authority exists when the principal’s words or conduct cause a reasonable third party to believe the agent is authorized, even if the agent lacks actual authority. The principal’s manifestation, not the agent’s say-so, is key.
cards.mediumContent: An agent has apparent authority when the principal holds the agent out as having authority and the principal’s words, conduct, or inaction cause a reasonable third party to rely on the agent’s apparent authority. If the third party knows the agent lacks actual authority, there is no apparent authority. The principal must create or allow the appearance of authority; the agent’s unilateral claims are not enough. Apparent authority focuses on the reasonable third party’s belief, unlike actual authority, which focuses on the reasonable agent’s belief.
cards.hardContent: Even without actual authority, a principal can be bound if the agent acts with apparent authority. Apparent authority arises when (1) the principal holds the agent out as having authority to act on the principal’s behalf, and (2) the principal’s conduct (including in some cases inaction where there is a duty to speak) causes a third party to reasonably rely on the agent’s apparent authority. A mere assertion of authority by the agent is insufficient. If the third party knows the agent lacks actual authority, apparent authority cannot exist. Apparent authority is based on the principal’s words or conduct as reasonably understood by a third party, whereas actual authority is based on the principal’s manifestations as reasonably understood by the agent.
cards.mnemonic: APPARENT: Authority Presented Publicly, Affecting Reasonable ENTity (third party).
cards.clozeLite: An agent has {{c1::apparent authority}} when the {{c2::principal holds the agent out as authorized}} and a {{c3::reasonable third party relies}} on that appearance.

cards.subject: Agency
cards.backPlain: Where an agent purports to act on behalf of a principal but lacks authority to do so, the principal may still be bound by the agent's acts if the principal subsequently ratifies the acts. 1. Requirements 1.1 Agent purported to act on the principal's behalf. For example, the agent entered into a contract with a third party without authority to do so. 1.2 Principal has knowledge of material facts of the act (such as the contract terms). The principal must know or reasonably should know the material facts when the agent's act is affirmed or ratified. 1.3 Principal affirmed (ratified) the agent's conduct. 1.3.1 Affirmance can be express or implied (conduct by the principal consistent with approval of the otherwise unauthorized act). 1.3.2 If the principal accepts the benefits of the agent's act when it is still possible to decline, the principal will be deemed to have ratified the agent's act. 2. Effect of ratification 2.1 A principal who ratifies an agent's unauthorized act becomes liable to third parties for those acts. For example, if a principal ratifies a contract the agent entered into without authority, the principal is bound to the contract and can be held liable to the third party.
cards.frontPrompt: What is ratification in agency law, what are its requirements, and what is the effect of ratification on the principal’s liability?
cards.cloze: Where an agent {{c1::purports to act on behalf of a principal but lacks authority}} to do so, the principal may still be bound by the agent's acts if the principal subsequently {{c2::ratifies}} the acts. 1. {{c3::Requirements}} 1.1 Agent {{c4::purported to act on the principal's behalf}}. For example, the agent entered into a contract with a third party without authority to do so. 1.2 Principal has {{c5::knowledge of material facts}} of the act (such as the contract terms). The principal must know or reasonably should know the material facts when the agent's act is affirmed or ratified. 1.3 Principal {{c6::affirmed (ratified) the agent's conduct}}. 1.3.1 Affirmance can be {{c7::express or implied}} (conduct by the principal consistent with approval of the otherwise unauthorized act). 1.3.2 If the principal {{c8::accepts the benefits}} of the agent's act when it is still possible to decline, the principal will be deemed to have ratified the agent's act. 2. {{c9::Effect of ratification}} 2.1 A principal who ratifies an agent's unauthorized act becomes {{c10::liable to third parties}} for those acts. For example, if a principal ratifies a contract the agent entered into without authority, the principal is bound to the contract and can be held liable to the third party.
cards.easyContent: Ratification occurs when a principal retroactively accepts an agent’s unauthorized act done on the principal’s behalf, with knowledge of the material facts. Once ratified, the principal is bound as if the act had been authorized from the start.
cards.mediumContent: Ratification allows a principal to be bound by an agent’s unauthorized act when the agent purported to act for the principal, the principal knows or should know the material facts, and the principal affirms the act, either expressly or impliedly. Accepting the benefits of the transaction while able to reject it is implied ratification. Ratification makes the principal liable on the contract or transaction as if authority had existed at the time of the act.
cards.hardContent: When an agent, without authority, purports to act on behalf of a principal (for example, by entering a contract with a third party), the principal can nonetheless be bound if she subsequently ratifies the act. Ratification requires: (1) the agent purported to act on the principal’s behalf; (2) the principal knows or should know the material facts of the transaction at the time of ratification; and (3) the principal affirms the agent’s conduct, either expressly or impliedly. Affirmance may be implied by conduct consistent with approval, including accepting the benefits of the transaction when it is still possible to decline them. A principal who ratifies an unauthorized act becomes liable to the third party as though the agent had actual authority at the time, and the principal is bound to the contract or transaction.
cards.mnemonic: RATIFY: Retroactively Accept Transaction; It Fixes Your liability.
cards.clozeLite: Agency {{c1::ratification}} lets a {{c2::principal}} adopt an {{c3::unauthorized act}} done on her behalf, with {{c4::knowledge of material facts}} and {{c5::affirmance (express or implied)}}.

cards.subject: Agency
cards.topic: Liabilities of Agents and Principals to Third Parties
cards.rawHeader: Agency 009. Liabilities of Agents and Principals to Third Parties
cards.front: Liabilities of Agents and Principals to Third Parties
cards.backPlain: Once a valid contract is entered into by an agent with a third party on the principal's behalf, the liabilities of the principal and the agent to the third party depend on whether the principal was disclosed to the third party. 1. Third party vs. principal 1.1 If the agent had authority, the principal is liable to the third party. 2. Third party vs. agent (liability of the agent depends on whether the principal is disclosed) 2.1 Disclosed principal: where the third party knows of the principal's existence and identity: 2.1.1 The principal is liable; the agent is not liable. 2.1.2 Only the principal, not the agent, can enforce the contract. 2.2 Undisclosed and/or unidentified principal: both the agent and the principal are liable to the third party, and either can enforce the contract. If the agent enforces the contract, the principal is entitled to all rights and benefits under the contract. Definitions 3.1 Undisclosed principal: the third party does not know of the principal's existence or identity. 3.2 Unidentified principal: the third party knows that a principal exists but does not know the principal's identity.
cards.frontPrompt: How does disclosure of the principal affect the liability of the principal and the agent to third parties on a contract, and what are disclosed, undisclosed, and unidentified principals?
cards.cloze: Once a valid {{c1::contract}} is entered into by an agent with a third party on the principal's behalf, the liabilities of the principal and the agent to the third party depend on whether the principal was {{c2::disclosed}} to the third party. 1. {{c3::Third party vs. principal}} 1.1 If the {{c4::agent had authority}}, the principal is liable to the third party. 2. {{c5::Third party vs. agent}} (liability of the agent depends on whether the principal is disclosed) 2.1 {{c6::Disclosed principal}}: where the third party knows of the principal's existence and identity: 2.1.1 The {{c7::principal is liable}}; the {{c8::agent is not liable}}. 2.1.2 Only the {{c9::principal}}, not the agent, can {{c10::enforce the contract}}. 2.2 {{c11::Undisclosed and/or unidentified principal}}: both the {{c12::agent and the principal are liable}} to the third party, and {{c13::either can enforce}} the contract. If the agent enforces the contract, the principal is entitled to all {{c14::rights and benefits}} under the contract. Definitions 3.1 {{c15::Undisclosed principal}}: the third party does not know of the principal's existence or identity. 3.2 {{c16::Unidentified principal}}: the third party knows that a principal exists but does not know the principal's identity.
cards.easyContent: If an authorized agent contracts on a principal’s behalf, the principal is liable to the third party. With a disclosed principal, only the principal (not the agent) is liable and can enforce the contract; with an undisclosed or unidentified principal, both principal and agent are liable and either can enforce.
cards.mediumContent: When an agent with authority contracts for a principal, the principal is liable to the third party. If the principal is disclosed (third party knows both existence and identity), the principal is liable and the agent is not; only the principal can enforce the contract. If the principal is undisclosed (third party does not know of a principal) or unidentified (knows a principal exists but not who it is), both the principal and the agent are liable and either can enforce, though the principal ultimately receives the contract’s benefits.
cards.hardContent: When an authorized agent enters a valid contract with a third party on behalf of a principal, liability allocation turns on disclosure of the principal. As between third party and principal, if the agent had authority, the principal is liable. As between third party and agent: (1) with a disclosed principal—where the third party knows both the principal’s existence and identity—the principal is liable and the agent is not, and only the principal may enforce the contract; (2) with an undisclosed or unidentified principal—where the third party either does not know there is a principal at all, or knows a principal exists but not its identity—both the agent and the principal are liable to the third party, and either may enforce the contract. If the agent enforces, the principal is entitled to the rights and benefits under the contract. An undisclosed principal is unknown in both existence and identity; an unidentified principal’s existence is known but not its identity.
cards.mnemonic: D = Disclosed: Deal only with principal; U = Undisclosed/Unidentified: Unclear, so both may pay.
cards.clozeLite: With a {{c1::disclosed principal}}, only the {{c2::principal is liable and can enforce}}. With an {{c3::undisclosed or unidentified principal}}, {{c4::both principal and agent are liable and either can enforce}}.

cards.subject: Agency
cards.backPlain: Principals may be held liable to third parties for torts committed by their agents acting as employees or servants. Respondeat superior is the doctrine under which principal liability arises for torts committed within the scope of agency or employment. For torts committed outside that scope (where respondeat superior does not apply) the principal can still be liable if the agent acted with authority. 1. Requirements (principal will be liable where): 1.1 An employer-employee relationship exists between the principal and the party who caused the injury; the principal is generally not liable for independent contractors. 1.2 The tortious conduct was committed within the scope of employment, meaning: 1.2.1 The conduct was the same or similar in nature to that which the employee was hired to perform; 1.2.2 The tort was committed in service of the employer; and/or 1.2.3 The conduct was intended, at least in part, to further the employer's goals. 2. Intentional torts 2.1 The employer is usually not liable because intentional torts are usually outside the scope of employment. 2.2 Exception: the employer can be held liable where the intentional tort occurs as a natural incident of carrying out the employer's business (for example, a bouncer using force while ejecting patrons).
cards.frontPrompt: Under the doctrine of respondeat superior, when is a principal (employer) liable for an employee’s torts, and how are intentional torts treated?
cards.cloze: Principals may be held liable to third parties for torts committed by their agents acting as {{c1::employees or servants}}. {{c2::Respondeat superior}} is the doctrine under which principal liability arises for torts committed within the {{c3::scope of agency or employment}}. For torts committed outside that scope (where respondeat superior does not apply) the principal can still be liable if the agent {{c4::acted with authority}}. 1. {{c5::Requirements}} (principal will be liable where): 1.1 An {{c6::employer-employee relationship}} exists between the principal and the party who caused the injury; the principal is generally not liable for {{c7::independent contractors}}. 1.2 The tortious conduct was committed {{c8::within the scope of employment}}, meaning: 1.2.1 The conduct was the {{c9::same or similar in nature}} to that which the employee was hired to perform; 1.2.2 The tort was committed {{c10::in service of the employer}}; and/or 1.2.3 The conduct was intended, at least in part, to {{c11::further the employer's goals}}. 2. {{c12::Intentional torts}} 2.1 The employer is usually {{c13::not liable}} because intentional torts are usually outside the scope of employment. 2.2 {{c14::Exception}}: the employer can be held liable where the intentional tort occurs as a {{c15::natural incident of carrying out the employer's business}} (for example, a bouncer using force while ejecting patrons).
cards.easyContent: Respondeat superior makes an employer liable for an employee’s torts committed within the scope of employment, but usually not for independent contractors or for intentional torts, unless the intentional tort is a natural part of the job.
cards.mediumContent: Under respondeat superior, a principal is liable for torts committed by an employee (not an independent contractor) acting within the scope of employment—i.e., doing the kind of work hired to do, in service of the employer, and at least partly to further the employer’s goals. For acts outside that scope, the principal may still be liable if the agent independently had authority. Employers are usually not liable for employees’ intentional torts, unless the intentional tort is a natural incident of carrying out the employer’s business (such as a security guard using force).
cards.hardContent: Respondeat superior is the vicarious liability doctrine under which a principal (employer) is liable for torts committed by an agent who is an employee or servant, when those torts are committed within the scope of agency or employment. Liability requires: (1) an employer-employee relationship (the principal is generally not liable for independent contractors); and (2) tortious conduct within the scope of employment, meaning the conduct is the same or similar in nature to the work the employee was hired to perform, is undertaken in the service of the employer, and is intended at least in part to further the employer's goals. For torts outside the scope, respondeat superior does not apply, though the principal might still be liable if the agent acted with actual or apparent authority. Employers are ordinarily not liable for intentional torts of employees, because such acts are usually outside the scope of employment, but liability may arise when the intentional tort is a natural, foreseeable incident of the employer’s business (for example, a bouncer or security guard using force in dealing with patrons).
cards.mnemonic: MASTER pays when SERVANT acts in scope.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::respondeat superior}}, an employer is liable for an {{c2::employee’s}} torts committed {{c3::within the scope of employment}}, but usually not for {{c4::independent contractors}} or {{c5::intentional torts}}.

cards.subject: Agency
cards.topic: Principal's Liability for Independent Contractor Torts
cards.rawHeader: Agency 011. Principal's Liability for Independent Contractor Torts
cards.front: Principal's Liability for Independent Contractor Torts
cards.backPlain: Principals are generally not liable for acts committed by independent contractors because their work is outside the scope of an employment/servant-type agency relationship. 1. Distinguishing independent contractors from an employment/servant relationship: 1.1. The distinction turns on the principal/employer's right to control the manner and method by which a person performs their job. 1.2. Employment relationship: the employee is compensated on a time basis (e.g., per hour, per year, etc.), and the employer has a right to control the manner and method by which the employee performs the job. 1.3. Independent-contractor relationship: the independent contractor is hired to do a particular job, is paid a given amount for that particular job, and the principal has limited rights to control the manner and method in which the independent contractor performs. 2. Principal's liability for independent-contractor acts: 2.1. Public policy dictates that principals should be liable for certain torts committed by independent contractors. 2.2. Principals can be held liable for independent-contractor torts where: 2.2.1. The contractor is performing inherently dangerous activities (acts performed by the independent contractor that are, by nature, inherently dangerous); or 2.2.2. The principal knowingly hires an incompetent independent contractor.
cards.frontPrompt: When is a principal liable for torts committed by an independent contractor, and how do you distinguish an independent contractor from an employee/servant?
cards.cloze: Principals are generally not liable for acts committed by {{c1::independent contractors}} because their work is outside the scope of an {{c2::employment/servant-type agency relationship}}. 1. Distinguishing independent contractors from an employment/servant relationship: 1.1. The distinction turns on the principal/employer's right to {{c3::control the manner and method by which a person performs their job}}. 1.2. {{c4::Employment relationship}}: the employee is compensated on a time basis (e.g., per hour, per year, etc.), and the employer has a right to control the manner and method by which the employee performs the job. 1.3. {{c5::Independent-contractor relationship}}: the independent contractor is hired to do a particular job, is paid a given amount for that particular job, and the principal has {{c6::limited rights to control the manner and method}} in which the independent contractor performs. 2. Principal's liability for independent-contractor acts: 2.1. {{c7::Public policy}} dictates that principals should be liable for certain torts committed by independent contractors. 2.2. Principals can be held liable for independent-contractor torts where: 2.2.1. The contractor is performing {{c8::inherently dangerous activities}} (acts performed by the independent contractor that are, by nature, inherently dangerous); or 2.2.2. The principal {{c9::knowingly hires an incompetent independent contractor}}.
cards.easyContent: A principal is usually not liable for torts of an independent contractor, but can be liable for inherently dangerous activities or for knowingly hiring an incompetent contractor. The key distinction is the principal’s right to control the manner and method of work.
cards.mediumContent: A principal is generally not vicariously liable for torts of an independent contractor because the work is outside a servant-type relationship. An employee is paid on a time basis and is subject to the employer’s right to control the manner and method of work, while an independent contractor is hired for a particular job, paid for that job, and subject to only limited control. Public policy creates exceptions: the principal is liable when the contractor performs inherently dangerous activities or when the principal knowingly hires an incompetent contractor.
cards.hardContent: Principals are generally not liable for acts committed by independent contractors because their work is outside the scope of an employment/servant-type agency relationship. The distinction between an independent contractor and an employee turns on the principal’s right to control the manner and method of work: employees are typically compensated on a time basis and are subject to the employer’s detailed control, while independent contractors are hired and paid for a particular job with only limited control by the principal. Despite the general rule, public policy imposes liability on principals for independent-contractor torts when the contractor is engaged in inherently dangerous activities or when the principal knowingly hires an incompetent independent contractor.
cards.mnemonic: IC liability is rare: D.I.C.—Dangerous work or Incompetent Contractor.
cards.clozeLite: A principal is {{c1::generally not vicariously liable}} for {{c2::independent contractor}} torts, except for {{c3::inherently dangerous activities}} or {{c4::knowingly hiring an incompetent contractor}}.

cards.subject: Agency
cards.backPlain: Agency concerns the relationship that exists between an agent and a principal whereby the agent acts on the principal's behalf and is subject to the principal's control. • Principal: the person for whom the agent acts. • Agent: the person who acts on the principal’s behalf and is subject to the principal’s control. Key ideas: • The agent acts primarily for the benefit of the principal. • The principal has the right to control the agent’s conduct in matters entrusted to the agent.
cards.frontPrompt: What is an agency relationship, and who are the principal and the agent in that relationship?
cards.cloze: Agency concerns the relationship that exists between an {{c1::agent}} and a {{c2::principal}} whereby the agent {{c3::acts on the principal's behalf}} and is subject to the principal's {{c4::control}}. The {{c5::principal}} is the person for whom the agent acts, and the {{c6::agent}} is the person who acts on the principal’s behalf and is subject to the principal’s control.
cards.easyContent: Agency is a relationship where an agent acts on behalf of a principal and is subject to the principal’s control.
cards.mediumContent: Agency is a legal relationship between a principal and an agent. The agent acts on the principal’s behalf and is subject to the principal’s control, meaning the principal has the right to direct or supervise the agent’s work.
cards.hardContent: Agency is a legal relationship between an agent and a principal whereby the agent acts on the principal's behalf and is subject to the principal's control. The principal is the person for whom the agent acts, and the agent is the person who acts for the principal and is subject to the principal’s control. The agent generally acts primarily for the benefit of the principal, and the principal retains the right to control the agent’s conduct in matters entrusted to the agent.
cards.mnemonic: ABC: Agent Benefits and is Controlled by principal
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::agency relationship}} exists when an {{c2::agent}} {{c3::acts on behalf of}} and is {{c4::subject to the control}} of a {{c5::principal}}.

cards.subject: Agency
cards.topic: Agency – Elements of Creation (Consent, Control, Acting on Behalf)
cards.rawHeader: Agency 001-2. Agency – Elements of Creation (Consent, Control, Acting on Behalf)
cards.backPlain: An agency relationship is created when all three of the following are present: 1. Consent • The parties expressly or impliedly agree to enter an agency relationship. • Consent can be shown by words or conduct; it need not be formal. 2. Control • The agent is subject to the principal's control. • The principal has the right to control or at least supervise the agent’s work. 3. Acting on Behalf of the Principal • The agent is acting on behalf of the principal. • Generally means the agent is acting primarily for the benefit of the principal, not for the agent’s own benefit. Mnemonic: CCA – Consent, Control, Acting on behalf.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the three elements required to create an agency relationship, and what does each require?
cards.cloze: An agency relationship is created when all three of the following are present: 1. {{c1::Consent}} – the parties expressly or impliedly agree to enter an agency relationship. 2. {{c2::Control}} – the agent is subject to the principal's control, meaning the principal has the right to direct or supervise the agent’s work. 3. {{c3::Acting on behalf}} – the agent is acting on behalf of the principal, generally acting primarily for the principal’s benefit. Mnemonic: {{c4::CCA}} – Consent, Control, Acting on behalf.
cards.easyContent: Agency is created when there is CCA: consent to an agency relationship, the principal’s right to control the agent, and the agent acting on behalf of the principal.
cards.mediumContent: An agency relationship is created when (1) the parties consent, expressly or impliedly, to an agency relationship; (2) the principal has the right to control the agent, such as by supervising the agent’s work; and (3) the agent acts on behalf of the principal, primarily for the principal’s benefit. These are often remembered as CCA: Consent, Control, Acting on behalf.
cards.hardContent: An agency relationship is created only when three elements are present: (1) Consent – the parties expressly or impliedly agree to an agency relationship, shown by words or conduct; (2) Control – the agent is subject to the principal's control, meaning the principal has the right to direct or at least supervise the agent’s performance; and (3) Acting on behalf – the agent acts on behalf of the principal, generally acting primarily for the principal’s benefit rather than for the agent’s own purposes. All three must be present for a true agency relationship.
cards.mnemonic: CCA: Consent, Control, Acting on behalf.
cards.clozeLite: Agency requires {{c1::Consent}}, {{c2::Control}}, and {{c3::Acting on behalf}}—the agent acts {{c4::primarily for the principal’s benefit}}.

cards.subject: Agency
cards.topic: Agency – Methods of Creation (Agreement, Apparent Authority, Ratification)
cards.rawHeader: Agency 001-3. Agency – Methods of Creation (Agreement, Apparent Authority, Ratification)
cards.front: Agency – Methods of Creation (Agreement, Apparent Authority, Ratification)
cards.backPlain: An agency relationship can be created by any of the following methods (assuming the elements of agency are satisfied): 1. Agreement by the Parties • The principal and agent agree (expressly or impliedly) to the agency. • A writing is not required unless another doctrine (e.g., Statute of Frauds) applies. 2. Apparent Authority • The principal holds another out as her agent to a third party. • The third party reasonably believes, based on the principal’s manifestations, that the person is authorized to act for the principal. • This can create an agency relationship as to the third party for purposes of binding the principal. 3. Ratification • The principal agrees retroactively to be bound by the previously unauthorized acts of an agent (or a purported agent). • Ratification requires knowledge of material facts and acceptance of the transaction’s benefits (or other manifestation of intent to be bound). In each method, the underlying agency elements (consent, control, acting on behalf) must ultimately be satisfied for a true agency relationship.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main methods by which an agency relationship can be created, and what does each method involve?
cards.cloze: An agency relationship can be created by: 1. {{c1::Agreement by the parties}} – the principal and agent agree, expressly or impliedly, to the agency; a writing is not required. 2. {{c2::Apparent authority}} – the principal {{c3::holds another out as her agent}} to a third party, causing the third party reasonably to believe the person is authorized to act for the principal. 3. {{c4::Ratification}} – the principal {{c5::retroactively agrees to be bound}} by the previously unauthorized acts of an agent or purported agent, with knowledge of material facts and acceptance of the transaction or its benefits.
cards.easyContent: Agency can arise by agreement of the parties, by apparent authority when the principal holds someone out as an agent, or by ratification when the principal later agrees to be bound by an unauthorized act.
cards.mediumContent: Agency may be created by (1) agreement of the parties (no writing required unless another rule demands it); (2) apparent authority, when the principal holds another out as her agent to a third party, leading the third party reasonably to believe the person is authorized; or (3) ratification, when the principal later agrees to be bound by a previously unauthorized act with knowledge of the material facts.
cards.hardContent: An agency relationship can arise through several methods, provided that the core elements of agency (consent, control, acting on behalf) are ultimately present: (1) Agreement by the parties, where the principal and agent expressly or impliedly agree to the agency; no writing is required unless some other doctrine such as the Statute of Frauds applies. (2) Apparent authority, where the principal holds another out as her agent to a third party, causing the third party reasonably to believe, based on the principal’s manifestations, that the person is authorized to act for the principal; this can bind the principal as to that third party. (3) Ratification, where the principal, with knowledge of material facts, retroactively agrees to be bound by a previously unauthorized act of an agent or purported agent, such as by expressly affirming the transaction or accepting its benefits.
cards.mnemonic: Agency forms by AAR: Agreement, Apparent authority, Ratification.
cards.clozeLite: Agency may be created by {{c1::agreement of the parties}}, {{c2::apparent authority}}, or {{c3::ratification}} by the principal.

cards.subject: Agency
cards.topic: Agent Authority – Actual Authority & Principal Liability
cards.rawHeader: Agency 005-1. Agent Authority – Actual Authority & Principal Liability
cards.front: Agent Authority – Actual Authority & Principal Liability
cards.backPlain: Step 1: Actual Authority 1. Ask first: Did the agent have actual authority? - Actual authority exists when the principal has authorized the agent (expressly or impliedly) to act on the principal’s behalf and the agent reasonably believes she is so empowered. 2. Effect of actual authority on the principal: - If the agent had actual authority, the principal is bound to the contract entered into by the agent with the third party. - This is true regardless of whether the third party knew about, or even believed in, the agent’s authority. 3. Effect of actual authority on the agent: - When the agent acts within the scope of her actual authority, she generally cannot be held liable to the principal for entering into the contract. - The agent may still have duties to the principal (e.g., fiduciary duties), but merely contracting within authorized bounds does not create liability to the principal.
cards.frontPrompt: In analyzing principal liability for an agent’s contract, what is the role of actual authority, and what are its consequences for the principal and the agent?
cards.cloze: Step 1: {{c1::Actual authority}} 1. Ask first: Did the agent have {{c2::actual authority}}? - Actual authority exists when the {{c3::principal has authorized the agent}} (expressly or impliedly) to act on the principal’s behalf and the agent {{c4::reasonably believes}} she is so empowered. 2. Effect of actual authority on the principal: - If the agent had actual authority, the {{c5::principal is bound}} to the contract entered into by the agent with the third party. - This is true regardless of whether the {{c6::third party knew}} about, or even believed in, the agent’s authority. 3. Effect of actual authority on the agent: - When the agent acts within the {{c7::scope of her actual authority}}, she generally {{c8::cannot be held liable to the principal}} for entering into the contract. - Merely contracting within authorized bounds does not itself create liability from the agent to the principal.
cards.easyContent: First ask whether the agent had actual authority. If the principal has authorized the agent and the agent reasonably believes she is empowered, the principal is bound to the contract, even if the third party did not know of the authority, and the agent is not liable to the principal so long as she acted within her authority.
cards.mediumContent: Step one in analyzing principal liability is actual authority. Actual authority arises when the principal authorizes the agent (expressly or impliedly) and the agent reasonably believes she is empowered. If actual authority exists, the principal is bound to the contract regardless of the third party’s knowledge, and an agent who acts within the scope of her actual authority is generally not liable to the principal for entering into the contract.
cards.hardContent: In determining whether a principal is bound by an agent’s contract with a third party, the first question is whether the agent had actual authority. Actual authority exists when the principal authorizes the agent—either expressly (e.g., specific instructions) or impliedly (e.g., authority reasonably necessary to carry out express directives)—and the agent reasonably believes she is empowered to act on the principal’s behalf. If actual authority is present, the principal will be bound to the contract the agent enters into, even if the third party is unaware of the agent’s authority or doubts its existence. As to the agent, acting within the scope of actual authority shields her from liability to the principal for entering the contract; she is doing exactly what the principal empowered her to do, though she still owes separate fiduciary and contractual duties to the principal.
cards.mnemonic: Actual authority: actually authorized, principal bound, agent safe in scope.
cards.clozeLite: Step one is {{c1::actual authority}}: the {{c2::principal authorizes the agent}} and the {{c3::agent reasonably believes she is empowered}}. Then the {{c4::principal is bound}} and the {{c5::agent is not liable to the principal if within scope}}.

cards.subject: Agency
cards.topic: Agent Authority – Apparent Authority, Ratification & Consequences
cards.rawHeader: Agency 005-2. Agent Authority – Apparent Authority, Ratification & Consequences
cards.front: Agent Authority – Apparent Authority, Ratification & Consequences
cards.backPlain: Step 2: Apparent Authority 1. If the agent lacked actual authority, ask: Did the agent have apparent authority? - Apparent authority arises when the principal’s manifestations to the third party cause the third party reasonably to believe the agent is authorized. 2. Effect of apparent authority on the principal: - Apparent authority will bind the principal to the contract the agent makes with the third party. 3. Effect of apparent authority on the agent: - The agent may be held liable to the principal for acting beyond the scope of her actual authority, even though the principal is bound to the third party. Step 3: Ratification 1. If there is no actual or apparent authority, ask: Did the principal ratify the agent’s unauthorized act? - Ratification occurs when the principal, with knowledge of all material facts, affirms or accepts the benefits of the agent’s unauthorized transaction. 2. Effect of ratification: - Ratification can bind the principal to the agent’s previously unauthorized conduct as if it had been authorized from the outset. - The principal may still have claims against the agent for acting without prior authority, depending on their relationship and the circumstances.
cards.frontPrompt: If an agent lacked actual authority, how can a principal still be bound through apparent authority or ratification, and what are the consequences for the principal and the agent?
cards.cloze: Step 2: {{c1::Apparent authority}} 1. If the agent lacked actual authority, ask: Did the agent have {{c2::apparent authority}}? - Apparent authority arises when the {{c3::principal’s manifestations to the third party}} cause the third party {{c4::reasonably to believe}} the agent is authorized. 2. Effect of apparent authority on the principal: - Apparent authority will {{c5::bind the principal}} to the contract the agent makes with the third party. 3. Effect of apparent authority on the agent: - The agent may be {{c6::liable to the principal}} for acting {{c7::beyond the scope of her actual authority}}, even though the principal is bound to the third party. Step 3: {{c8::Ratification}} 1. If there is no actual or apparent authority, ask: Did the principal {{c9::ratify}} the agent’s unauthorized act? - Ratification occurs when the principal, with {{c10::knowledge of all material facts}}, {{c11::affirms or accepts the benefits}} of the agent’s unauthorized transaction. 2. Effect of ratification: - Ratification can {{c12::bind the principal}} to the agent’s previously unauthorized conduct as if it had been {{c13::authorized from the outset}}. - The principal may still have {{c14::claims against the agent}} for acting without prior authority, depending on their relationship and the circumstances.
cards.easyContent: If the agent lacked actual authority, the principal can still be bound if the agent had apparent authority—where the principal’s words or conduct made the third party reasonably think the agent was authorized. The principal is bound, but the agent may be liable to the principal for going beyond her actual authority. Even without actual or apparent authority, the principal can become bound later by ratifying the agent’s unauthorized act with full knowledge of the facts.
cards.mediumContent: After ruling out actual authority, ask about apparent authority: did the principal’s manifestations cause the third party reasonably to believe the agent was authorized? If so, the principal is bound to the contract, but the agent may be liable to the principal for exceeding her actual authority. If neither actual nor apparent authority exists, consider ratification: with knowledge of all material facts, the principal can affirm or accept the benefits of the unauthorized transaction, thereby binding herself as though it had been authorized originally, though she may still have claims against the agent for acting without prior authority.
cards.hardContent: Once you conclude an agent had no actual authority, move to apparent authority. Apparent authority arises when the principal’s manifestations—through words, conduct, or in some situations inaction—lead the third party reasonably to believe the agent is authorized to act on the principal’s behalf. If apparent authority is present, the principal is bound to the contract the agent makes with the third party. However, because the agent has gone beyond the scope of her actual authority, the principal may have a claim against the agent for breaching duties owed to the principal. If neither actual nor apparent authority is present, the principal may still become bound if she ratifies the agent’s conduct. Ratification requires that the principal, with knowledge of all material facts of the transaction, affirm it (expressly or impliedly) or accept its benefits. Once ratified, the transaction is treated as if it had been authorized from the beginning, binding the principal to the third party, while still leaving open potential claims the principal might have against the agent for acting without advance authority.
cards.mnemonic: No actual? Think APeR: Apparent, then Ratification.
cards.clozeLite: If an agent lacks actual authority, the principal may still be bound by {{c1::apparent authority}} or by {{c2::ratification}} with {{c3::knowledge of all material facts}}.
